channel.title: Interleaved RSS Feed
channel.description: This is an interleaved feed of the most recent entries from each RSS source, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: How to Reboot Free Speech on Campus
item.description: How do we find our way to a campus culture in which everyone can be heard?

item.title: Tornado Kills 5 in Guangzhou, a Chinese City Battered by Recent Rains
item.description: Videos shared by Chinese official media showed transmission towers and power lines igniting and debris swirling in the air in the city, a manufacturing and technology hub by the Pearl River.

item.title: Should you sleep in socks? Experts say this hack might be the secret to falling asleep faster and waking up less
Radical Christians in South Korea Are Spreading a Homophobic Conspiracy Theory
item.description: Radical Christians are working to erase L.G.B.T.Q. visibility from schools and ultimately, South Korean society.

item.title: Hamas Says It Is Reviewing Israel’s Cease-Fire Proposal for Gaza
item.description: The statement came as anticipation was growing of an Israeli invasion of Rafah, where more than a million Gazans have been displaced.

item.title: 'We expect Powell to make a hawkish pivot'—Fed meeting to headline busy week for global markets
item.description: "At the minimum, he’ll likely indicate the median FOMC participant now expects ‘less’ cuts this year."

item.title: Biden and Colin Jost Address the White House Correspondents Dinner
item.description: Journalists and politicians schmoozed over filet mignon at the White House Correspondents Dinner as pro-Palestinian protesters gathered outside.

item.title: Israel Delivers More Aid to Gaza, but Threat of Famine Persists, U.N. Says
item.description: Israel says the number of trucks entering the enclave has doubled to an average of 400 a day. The U.N. disputes that, but agrees that the pace of deliveries has quickened.

item.title: Police bust 'very sophisticated' burglary ring that used Wi-Fi jammers to stea $4 million in jewels
item.description: The Providence-based theft crew broke into homes in 25 Massachusetts communities between July 21, 2018 and March 30.

item.title: More Than 170 Protesters Arrested at Northeastern and Arizona State University
item.description: The police made arrests at Washington University in St. Louis, Northeastern, Arizona State and Indiana, as more schools move in on encampments. The presidential candidate Jill Stein was among the arrests.

item.title: Heat Wave in Gaza Challenges Pharmacists Ability to Store Medicine
item.description: High temperatures this week have left people sweltering and challenged businesses that need to keep their products cool.

item.title: U.S. Secretary of State buys Taylor Swift album in China to wrap up key visit after warning on EV overproduction, Russia
item.description: Antony Blinken stopped at a Beijing record store where he bought albums by Taylor Swift and Chinese rocker Dou Wei in a symbolic nod to cross-cultural exchanges.

item.title: White House Correspondents’ Dinner Red Carpet Photos: See the Best Dressed
item.description: Scarlett Johansson, Colin Jost and Senator John Fetterman made their entrances at the annual journalism celebration in Washington.

item.title: Beneath London, Tunnels and Bomb Shelters to Become Tourist Attractions
item.description: Used for spying, a phone exchange and more over the years, a semi-secret web of tunnels in central London could open to the public in 2027.

item.title: It's time to talk about the 'dirty word' on Wall Street as 'whiffs of stagflation' intrude on markets, chief strategist says
item.description: "And that's why it was kind of shocking to see bond yields rise on a day where GDP was a big miss."
